org.ftccommunity.i2clibrary

Class ClassFactory

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.ftccommunity.i2clibrary.ClassFactory

  • public final class ClassFactory
extends java.lang.Object
    ClassFactory provides static methods for instantiating objects within the Swerve Robotics Library.

    The point here is to separate clients from having to know the actual class names or package structures in which various object implementations are stored; these are often internal, and thus should not be exposed to clients, as they are not stable from release to release.

      static class  ClassFactory.SENSOR_FLAVOR
      An enumeration of the various sensor manufacturers we are involved with

        See Also:

      • createAdaFruitBNO055IMU

        public static IBNO055IMU createAdaFruitBNO055IMU(com.qualcomm.robotcore.eventloop.opmode.OpMode context,
                                                 com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.I2cDevice i2cDevice,
                                                 IBNO055IMU.Parameters parameters)
        Instantiates a driver object for an AdaFruit BNO055 sensor which resides at the indicated I2cDevice using the provided configuration parameters.

        Features of this sensor include a gyro that does rate integration in hardware to provide robust and accurate angular position indications, and a separation of the output of the accelerometer into gravity and linear-motion-induced components.

        The driver builds on the linear-acceleration information to provide linear velocity and position measurements using integration in software. That said, the built-in accelerometer integration algorithm is quite naive. For a real robot, you'll want to do some investigation and reading and make a better one, whose use you can indicate using parameters.accelerationIntegrationAlgorithm.

        Also, while the out-of-box sensor BNO055 works remarkably well, Bosch describes a one-time calibration process that will make it even better (see Section 3.11). Perform this calibration process in the lab. Once you've got the sensor fully calibrated (or at least the gyro and the accelerometer), extract the configuration state with IBNO055IMU.readCalibrationData(). We suggest that you then incorporate the results as constants in your code, and provide them during OpMode startup in parameters.calibrationData where they will automatically be applied.

        Parameters:
        context - the OpMode within which this creation is taking place
        i2cDevice - the robot controller runtime object representing the sensor
        parameters - the parameters with which the sensor should be initialized
        Returns:
        the interface to the instantiated sensor object. This object also supports the II2cDeviceClientUser interface, which can be useful for debugging.
        See Also:
        createAdaFruitBNO055IMU(OpMode, I2cDevice)

      • createI2cDeviceClient

        public static II2cDeviceClient createI2cDeviceClient(com.qualcomm.robotcore.eventloop.opmode.OpMode context,
                                                     com.qualcomm.robotcore.hardware.I2cDevice i2cDevice,
                                                     int i2cAddr8Bit,
                                                     boolean closeOnOpModeStop)
        Create a new II2cDeviceClient on an I2cDevice instance. The client is initially disarmed, and must be armed before use.
        Parameters:
        context - the OpMode within which the creation is taking place
        i2cDevice - the II2cDevice to wrap
        i2cAddr8Bit - the I2C address at which the client is to communicate
        closeOnOpModeStop - if true, then when the OpMode stops, the client will automatically close
        Returns:
        the newly instantiated I2c device client
        See Also:
        II2cDeviceClient.arm()

                                                     boolean closeOnOpModeStop)

        i2cDevice - the II2cDevice to wrap
        i2cAddr8Bit - the I2C address at which the client is to communicate
        closeOnOpModeStop - if true, then when the OpMode stops, the client will automatically close

        See Also:
